Award.AwardTitle: NeTS: Small: Collaborative Research: A Green and Incentive Platform for Mobile Phone Sensing

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration: Sensors on mobile phones can enable attractive sensing applications in different domains such as environmental monitoring, social network, healthcare, etc. However, fundamental energy-efficient resource management problems have not been well studied for mobile phone sensing. In addition, how to provide incentives to attract user participation has not been well addressed. The objective of this project is to develop a unified and green platform for mobile phone sensing, optimize its performance by designing energy-efficient algorithms for sensing task management, and develop game-theoretic incentive mechanisms to attract user participation. The proposed research is organized into four cohesive research thrusts: 1) Design and implement a unified software architecture to enable support for various sensing applications. 2) Develop both platform-centric and user-centric incentive mechanisms to attract user participation. 3) Develop energy-efficient algorithms to manage sensing tasks. 4) Test the developed platform and algorithms via simulation and real experiments. This research will result in a unified and green mobile phone sensing system. Fundamental resource management problems will be solved by theoretically-sound and practical algorithms. The project will also result in novel incentive models and mechanisms for mobile phone sensing. In addition, the proposed platform can create a completely new type of online marketplace. The proposed energy-efficient algorithms can benefit both mobile users and the environment. The project is also expected to advance public understanding of mobile phone sensing via publications, seminars and workshops.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this project, the project team first introduced a novel mobile phone sensing based cloud service model: Sensing-as-a-Service, and developed a green and unified platform for Sensing-as-a-Service, which can support various sensing applications, and different embedded and external sensors. Based on this platform, two new mobile sensing applications were developed. The first application is SOR (mobile phone Sensing based Objective Ranking), which ranks target places according to (objective) data collected via mobile phone sensing and user preferences using a personalizable ranking algorithm. The second application is LIPS (LIfestyles of mobile users via mobile Phone Sensing), which leverages multiple sensors on a smartphone for obtaining a comprehensive view of the context (such as location, local weather, activities, etc.) of a mobile user over a long period, and to find out what a mobile user likes to do (characterization) and what he/she will do next (prediction) based on the collected sensor data.  Second, they developed a series of auction-based incentive mechanisms to attract mobile users to participant in mobile crowd sensing activities. For all the proposed mechanisms, they managed to formally prove that they have the following desirable properties: (1) Truthfulness: An auction is truthful if no individual can achieve a higher utility by reporting a value deviating from its true valuation (or cost) regardless of the bids (or asks) from other individuals. (2) Individual Rationality: An auction is individually rational if for any buyer or seller, it will not get a negative utility by revealing its true valuation (or cost). (3) Computational Efficiency: An auction is computationally efficient if the outcome can be computed in polynomial time. Moreover, they addressed Quality of Crowd (QoC) and critical security issues, such as free-riding and false-reporting. In addition, they studied several fundamental resource management problems for mobile crowd sensing. Particularly, they considered the problem of scheduling different sensing tasks assigned to a smartphone with the objective of minimizing sensing energy consumption while ensuring Quality of SenSing (QoSS), for which they designed an optimal polynomial-time algorithm for a special case and effective and efficient heuristic algorithms for the general case. Moreover, they designed a probabilistic model for sensing coverage without accurate location information (provided by GPS), and proposed provably-good approximation algorithms and a protocol for GPS-less energy-efficient sensing scheduling.

The project team has published 14 papers in premier conferences and journals. The PIs and their students delivered keynote speeches, presentations, and invited talks at numerous conferences and universities. A total of 9 Ph.D students were trained in this project, in which they learned machine learning, auction theory, game theory, and the state-of-the-art of the emerging technologies including smartphone sensing and mobile crowdsourcing; and they gained hands-on experience on mobile app programming and communication system development. Moreover, a female high-school student was involved in this project as a summer intern. She learned the basics of auction theory, mobile crowdsourcing and incentive mechanism design; and gained some research and development experience on modeling, analysis and website development. In addition, research results and findings have been integrated into three graduate courses, Cloud Computing (Syracuse University), Optimization with Network Applications (Arizona State University), and Game Theory with Network Applications (Arizona State University).
